classifai.title: The ClassifAI Project
classifai.paragraph: The Instructional Equity Observing Tool is an online video/audio analysis tool that is geared towards assisting the teachers and faculty of educational institutions in analyzing and understanding how their interaction with students translates into real learning. Our platform is meant to replace the current, manual method of analysis that many teachers/instructors perform to try and quantify different metrics about their teacher-student interaction. Instructors have expressed desire to view metrics such as the time the teacher talks during a lesson, what is the response time of students to those questions, and other data points such as the types of questions being asked (as categorized by Bloom’s Taxonomy). Quantifying these instructional variables helps these instructors more accurately understand the areas that they are strong in, and more importantly, the areas in which they can be more interactive with the students as to allow them to better absorb the lessons being taught. With the help of our tool (hosted at https://ai4c.eurekalabs.net), we can allow teachers to quickly and efficiently gather this data about each of their lessons so that data driven changes in teaching techniques is possible, and moreover, so that teachers can identify potential vectors of ineffective instruction.

team.name: Dr. Michael Faggella-Luby
team.paragraph: Dr. Faggella-Luby is a Professor of Special Education and Core Faculty of the Alice Neeley Special Education Research and Service (ANSERS) Institute.

team.name: Dr. Curby Alexander
team.paragraph: Curby Alexander is an Associate Professor of Professional Practice in the TCU College of Education. He teaches courses on the foundations of education, instructional methods, digital communication and collaboration, and experiential education. His current scholarship is focused on K-12 technology integration, cybersecurity education and workforce development, and geospatial education. For more information about Curby’s teaching, research, and writing, visit curbyalexander.net.

team.name: Dr. Liran Ma
team.paragraph: Dr. Ma is a Professor in the Department of Computer Science at Texas Christian University. His current research interests cover the security and reliability of networked information systems (such as Wi-Fi networks, cognitive radio networks, vehicular networks, sensor networks, social networks, and cloud services), and algorithms and protocols for smartphone based systems and applications (such as smart health and care), Internet of Things (IoT), artificial intelligence and security education.

team.name: Dr. Jonathan Cohen
team.paragraph: Jonathan Cohen (Jonathan D. Cohen) is an associate professor in the Department of Learning Sciences and an affiliate faculty member of the Curriculum and Instruction Ed.D program and the Master’s of Arts in Creative and Innovative Education program. His work explores teaching and learning in technology-supported constructionist learning environments. His research focuses both on the design, development, and implementation of constructionist curricula in formal and informal learning environments as well as on the infrastructure necessary to support the development and implementation of such curricula.

team.name: Dr. Zhipeng Cai
team.paragraph: Dr. Zhipeng Cai is a Professor in the Department of Computer Science at Georgia State University, an Affiliate Professor in the Department of Computer Information Systems at Robinson College of Business, and the Associate Director of Georgia State’s INSPIRE Center. Dr. Cai’s research expertise lies in the areas of resource management and scheduling, high-performance computing, cyber-security, privacy, networking, and big data.

team.name: Dr. Honghui Xu
team.paragraph: Dr. Honghui Xu is currently an Assistant Professor of Information Technology with Kennesaw State University, Kennesaw, GA, USA. He received a Ph.D. degree in computer science from Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA, USA, in 2023 and a Bachelor’s degree from University of Electronic Science and Technology of China. His research focuses on data privacy and security in AI, deep learning, and Internet of Things.

go2ai.title: The Go2AI Project
go2ai.paragraph: Our project was initially inspired by the advent of AlphaGo in 2016. AlphaGo was an artificial intelligence algorithm. In late 2015, it defeated a human professional player at the board game Go for the first time in history; this was a signal achievement in computer science in general, and a breakthrough in the field of AI in particular. Since then, successors of AlphaGo have reached even greater playing strength. The incorporation of artificial neural network was a critical feature in the design of those algorithms. The superhuman playing strength of the AI agents raises many interesting questions and challenges, among them the quantitative assessment of their strength, the probe, identification, and demonstration of deficiencies in the algorithms, and the possibility of their improvement with human aid. We are currently focusing on the study of such questions on a Go board of reduced size. We have already obtained certain definitive results, and have gained insights along the way. Our work has also spawned further, more foundational questions concerning AI design, especially artificial neural network. We look forward to doing further research on those questions as well—we have a long way “2 Go”!

team.name: Dr. Liran Ma
team.paragraph: Dr. Ma is a Professor in the Department of Computer Science at Texas Christian University. His current research interests cover the security and reliability of networked information systems (such as Wi-Fi networks, cognitive radio networks, vehicular networks, sensor networks, social networks, and cloud services), and algorithms and protocols for smartphone based systems and applications (such as smart health and care), Internet of Things (IoT), artificial intelligence and security education.

team.name: Dr. Ze-Li Dou
team.paragraph: Dr. Dou is an Associate Professor at the Department of Mathematics. His main research area is number theory. However, he maintains a curiosity in several other academic disciplines. In addition, he is an amateur Go player.

team.name: Kien X. Nguyen
team.paragraph: Kien is a Ph.D. student in the Department of Computer & Information Sciences at University of Delaware, focusing on Machine Learning. He obtained his B.S. at Texas Christian University.

team.name: Harrison Leath
team.paragraph: Harrison is an undergraduate student at Texas Christian University pursuing a major in Computer Science and a minor in Mathematics. He is an avid iOS developer having created and published a sticky note app called Jotify on the iOS App Store. Harrison also loves building computers and runs a high-capacity Linux server at home. He is the VP of Communications for his fraternity, Beta Theta Pi, and actively serves as a representative in TCU’s Student Government Association.

team.name: Blake Good
team.paragraph: Blake is an undergraduate student majoring in computer science at Texas Christian University. He has a deep interest in all things tech related, ranging from software development to building computers in his free time. Blake also serves as Vice President of the Google Developer Student Club at TCU.

airosettastone.title: AI Rosetta Stone
airosettastone.paragraph: In the annals of history, countless civilizations and cultures have left their mark through written languages. These linguistic relics contain the essence of human experience, conveying the stories, knowledge, and cultural heritage of their time. However, a significant number of these languages have been silenced by the sands of time, leaving us with a tantalizing glimpse into our past and a trove of untapped knowledge. This research project embarks on an ambitious and transformative journey to resurrect lost languages through the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI).

ailiteracyeducation.title: AI Literacy Education
ailiteracyeducation.paragraph: We plan to develop an introductory AI course at TCU, designed for all students. This interdisciplinary course will be led by a diverse team of faculty members, each bringing their unique expertise in AI as it applies to their respective fields. Our collaborative approach involves each instructor crafting and delivering their own AI-focused content over a 1-2 week period. Currently, we have nine enthusiastic faculty members from four different colleges within TCU, each committed to teaching a module. We are actively seeking additional instructors who are passionate about AI and eager to contribute to this innovative course. If you are interested in joining our team and shaping the AI education at TCU, we encourage you to come on board! Please contact Dr. Liran Ma (l.ma@tcu.edu) for further information.

findingnemo.title: Charting the voyage in the digital realm: Addressing the risk of substance use among youth aging out the child welfare system with AI informed intervention
findingnemo.paragraph: This project aims to develop and test an AI-powered intervention on substance use and related behavioral issues for youth in transition. The intervention will focus on two important types of psychosocial functioning underlying substance use in daily life: social communication and emotion regulation, and integrate two components: an AI-delivered personalized intervention and AI-powered in vivo assessment on intra-personal and ecological factors.

team.name: Dr. Yang Yang
team.paragraph: Yang Yang is a graduate of the IBR and joined the IBR as a Research Scientist in January 2020. Before returning to the IBR, she served as an Assistant Professor in the Department of Psychology at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette. She served as a PI on an externally funded project looking at factors associated with health-risk behaviors among young adults. Her research interests include substance use treatment for justice-involved individuals, health disparities, and advanced research methodology.
